rows.M0 THESIS — STRUCTURE & REQUIRED DECISIO: This is NOT the thesis. This is the structure the thesis must fill. Every field marked [NILO DECIDES] requires a real answer before production starts.

rows.col_3: Specific demographic. Not "health-conscious adults." Real: age range, income, lifestyle, buying triggers. Example: "Men 28-42, $75K+, train 4+x/week, currently buy LMNT or make their own ketoade, care about ingredient sourcing."
rows.col_5: Every TUP downstream reads this. If this is vague, everything is vague.

rows.col_3: Who else buys but isn't the bullseye. Example: "Women 25-35 in endurance sports who've tried Liquid IV and want something cleaner."
rows.col_5: Prevents scope creep. Secondary means "we'll take their money but we don't design for them."

rows.col_3: Who we explicitly do NOT want. Example: "Price-sensitive shoppers looking for the cheapest electrolyte. We will never compete on price."
rows.col_5: This is as important as the ICP. Saying no to someone sharpens everything.

rows.col_3: Complete the sentence: "IonWave is the only electrolyte that ___." Must be defensible and specific.
rows.col_5: This goes on the landing page, in every ad, in every pitch. It must be real.

rows.col_3: Where IonWave sits vs LMNT, Liquid IV, Drip Drop, Nuun, homemade. On what axes? (Price vs purity? Performance vs taste? Medical vs lifestyle?)
rows.col_5: PMs in CL-3 (product) and CL-4 (marketing) need to know who we're fighting and on what terms.

rows.col_3: Exact target price per serving and per unit/box. Not a range — a number. Example: "$1.50/serving, $36/30-pack."
rows.col_5: Drives COGS targets, margin model, ad economics, competitive positioning. Everything.

rows.col_3: What makes the product different at the ingredient level. Sodium/potassium/magnesium ratio. Any novel ingredients. Sourcing story.
rows.col_5: CL-3 (supply chain) builds from this. Without it, they're guessing.

rows.col_3: Stick pack? Tub? Tablet? Liquid? Pick one for launch. Example: "Stick packs. Single-serve. 30-count box."
rows.col_5: Drives packaging, COGS, shipping, shelf placement strategy.

rows.col_3: How many SKUs at launch? Which flavors? Example: "3 flavors at launch: citrus, berry, unflavored. Unflavored is the differentiator — most competitors don't offer it."
rows.col_5: Affects manufacturing complexity, COGS, marketing creative.

rows.col_3: DTC only? Amazon? Both? Retail? Example: "DTC-first via Shopify. Amazon 90 days after launch. No retail year 1."
rows.col_5: Determines CL-4 (marketing) strategy, funnel design, ad channel mix.

rows.col_3: How do customers find us? Paid? Organic? Creator partnerships? Example: "Organic-first leveraging Tabs content engine. Paid Meta/Google as amplifier. Creator seeding to 50 fitness accounts."
rows.col_5: CL-4 PM needs this to build the marketing operating model.

rows.col_3: Cost per unit target. Example: "$3-4 per 30-pack landed (stick pack, US contract manufacturer)."
rows.col_5: Determines margin structure, break-even math, fundraise ask.

rows.col_3: How much are we raising and at what stage? Example: "$250K pre-seed at $2.5M cap. Use: first inventory run + paid acquisition + 6 months ops."
rows.col_5: CL-5 (finance) PM builds the model from this number.

rows.col_3: Specific conditions under which we stop. Not "if it doesn't work." Real: "If COGS can't get below $5/unit, kill. If CAC exceeds $40 after 90 days of paid, kill. If no expert gives us above a C on CL-3 formulation thesis, kill."
rows.col_5: The most important section. Without kill criteria, you can't fail, which means you can't learn. This is what separates a protocol from a wish.

rows.col_3: When do we stop if we haven't hit milestones? Example: "If fewer than 4 clusters are locked by Week 10, pause and reassess. If fundraise doesn't close within 60 days of package completion, kill or pivot."
rows.col_5: Prevents zombie mode — keeping going because you've invested time, not because it's working.

rows.M0 THESIS — STRUCTURE & REQUIRED DECISIO: M0 IS NOT DONE UNTIL EVERY RED CELL IS FILLED WITH A REAL ANSWER.
